ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had virtual speaking clinics that met once weekly.
Four students would meet in-person and the other three students would join the class over Zoom.
Some classmates learned in person and others learned virtually.
In-person language class
A mixture between an in-person seminar and a live virtual seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of Japanese grammar and vocabulary.

I learned katakana, hiragana, and around 80 kanji, and the basics of everyday conversation (asking questions about family, talking about daily routines, talking about someone's physical characteristics and clothing, identifying where a building is, present and past dictionary- and te-form verbs, etc).
I learned basic Japanese: hiragana, katakana, some kanji, basic vocabulary and basic grammar.
I learned a surprisingly high amount of Japanese in a short time frame.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was intense and fast-paced, so I learned a lot. I would have preferred if we spent more time on speaking in class and had fewer tests, as we generally had 2-3 tests or quizzes every week.

This was a great introduction to Japanese. The class style -- learning most of the grammar outside of class and then reviewing the more difficult material and practicing conversation in class -- was effective for covering a lot of content without getting left behind. The homework occasionally felt a little bit like busywork, but it was often helpful for pinpointing misunderstandings of grammar and practicing vocabulary. It was enjoyable to be in class, and I felt motivated to study the material in order to perform well in class discussions.

The course is well taught and very organized. Another strength is that students will definitely receive quick, constructive feedback. Though it's not a weakness, students should be prepared to complete homework every weekday.
This class teaches a lot of Japanese. Although the workload is high, it was understandable in order to drill the language to stick in our minds.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was very small, so we were able to meet in person. This was very helpful.

The synchronous classes every day really works well. The engagement level was very high, and my listening and speaking really improved. Heard that other sections had one asynchronous class every week--pretty glad that my session didn't have this.

Starting about a month into the semester, Stever-sensei moved class in-person for the four people who could attend. The other three students joined the class over Zoom. I thought this was effective when I was in-person, but for days when I joined the in-person class over Zoom, I found it difficult to follow the conversation happening in the class.

I think in a language course like JAPN 110 specifically, virtual learning lacked a lot of elements that in-person learning provided. In addition, having some students learning in the classroom and others over Zoom led to some confusion due to lack of coordination.
Learning a language is best done in a seminar format and in person, so having the option to meet in person was helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but only a student prepared for the demanding workload of the course. It was taught well and the professor was always accommodating, but the workload was intense and constant.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I feel like I learned a lot of Japanese for only a semester (especially an online semester), I really did enjoy being in class, and I found the workload to be reasonable. The class was also really well-organized and it was easy to plan ahead.
Yes, the Japanese department has done a great job at designing this beginner course.
YES! Japanese is super fun
Yes, it's a great introduction to Japanese, and students get much out of the course if they're willing to put the time in.
